titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V:30. Sunday.

lg.l: O God, unto my prayer attend
O, lead me to the Rock on high
For I, from Earth’s remotest end
With heart oerwhelm’d to thee will cry
Thou art my Shelter, thou my Tower
My Soul to reach thy Temple Springs
Trusts to the refuge of thy Power
Safe in the covert of thy wings. Psalm 61. v. 1–4.

div.p: Began the day by reading the 4th. and two succeeding Chapters of Deuteronomy; and then made the version of the 61st Psalm, of which the above Stanza contains the first four verses or one-half— Deeming it eminently suited to the time and Circumstances I place it at the head of my Diary for the commencing year, and believe that the Trust in God which it imports is my sole reliance for this world and the next—in all humility imploring that support;—with this Sentiment I attended public worship at the second Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Smith from 27.1 “Boast not thy self of to-morrow; for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth.” From this most excellent text he delivered a well written and eloquent discourse—the first written Sermon that I have heard him preach—juvenile and florid, but full of Sentiment, and of sound morality.— I had morning visits from Mr Davis and G Bancroft, from Mr White of Florida, and his brother in Lawfrom W. Lee, and Baron Stackelberg; who could not suppress his eagerness for the recovery of Finland from Russia to Sweden— I heard Mr Smith again in the afternoon; from Ezekiel 2.7. “And thou shalt speak my words unto them, whether they will hear, or whether they will forbear: for they are most rebellious” This Sermon was unwritten, and was commendable principally for its brevity— Mr Smith has not much extemporaneous matter in his mind, and is not fruitful in his unwritten premeditations— He should write at least one of his Sermons weekly— I began yesterday the rough draft of a Report to be laid before the Committee of Manufactures.
2. VI. Monday.

Began the version of the 62d. Psalm— The Presidential Mansion was open this day at Noon, and some of its overflowings came over the Square— From Noon till three there was a succession of visitors—Foreign Legations, Members of Congress—Citizens Shawanese Indians and Quakers—Officers of the Army and Navy, and some Strangers— Among the company was Mr Smith the Register of the Treasury, and Major Lewis the second Auditor of the Treasury whom I did not know— In a casual conversation with them, I adverted to the remark of Gibbon, that the courage of a Soldier is the cheapest quality in human Nature— By the looks of some persons present, I saw it was thought I had a special meaning in what I said, when in truth it was a mere thoughtless indiscretion— Baron Huygens and his Sons—Mr Krehmer with another young Attaché of the Russian Legation,—Mr Bankhead and Mr William Pitt Adams, of the English Mission were here— Commodore Rodgers Genl. Gratiot—Coll. Abert; a number of Ladies and some children were here— Before dinner I walked round the Capitol Hill— Wrote an hour this Morning on the draft of a Report for the Committee on Manufactures—and Letters to H. Niles to Robert H. Hynal, at Dandridge, Tennessee, to whom at his request, I sent Copies of my Oration and Eulogy.
And in the Evening a Letter to T. L. M’Kenney, with a proof Sheet of his Indian History which I had received from him this morning with a Letter— I had received this morning Letters from Nathaniel Curtis my Co-executor of Ward N. Boylstons Will, with an enclosure from Petty Vaughan—from Jonathan Parker of Plympton—from James Birkard of New-York, about the duty upon Shawls—and from Isaac Candler enclosing an English pamphlet—a periodical, called the Anti-Slavery Reporter— This gentleman is scandalized at my remarks on presenting the Anti-Slavery Petitions.— Received also a Memorial from Citizens of Philadelphia, against the duties on Nova-Scotia-Coal, and a Lecture on the usefulness of Lyceums from Mr S. C. Phillips— I was disabled from writing or reading great part of the Evening, by my Cold.
3. IV:15. Tuesday

Finished the version of the 62d. Psalm— Dr Heuberger called this morning and took back his boxes of antient Coins and Medals back again. He said he had some prospect that the Government would take them for the Military Academy at West Point— On my way to the Capitol I stopped at Mr Hyatt’s and visited George Bancroft, J. Davis, Elutheros Cook—Andrew Stewart, and Ebenezer Young— Three other members were not at home— At the house— After the Petitions were offered there was a suspension of the ordinary rule to let in a General . . .ss of Resolutions— A debate upon a Memorial from Officers of the late War, who called it the second War of Independence— Sparring between R. M. Johnson—J. W. Taylor and T. Burges— Pendleton offered his Resolutions— R. H. Wilde moved to lay them on the Table question taken by Yeas and Nays. Ayes 99—Noes 89.— Mr Blair came and thanked me for the two pamphlets I had sent him. I answered the Letter from Francis Jackson, with the Petition from the Tallow-Chandlers in Boston— It was presented by Mr Appleton, and referred to the Committee on Manufactures— I sent round a notice to the Members to meet on Thursday morning at 11— I asked C. F. Mercer if the Committee on Internal Improvement had decided upon the petition from Scituate and Marshfield for the improvement of North River— They had not even received the Papers— This proves the necessity of attending to business before the Committees— House adjourned about three— I received a Letter from Mrs Decatur with a pamphlet upon her claim— One from Thomas Payson of Peterborough New-Hampshire: and several small pamphlets from Mr T. S. Grimke at Charleston S.C.
4. V:45. Wednesday— Fahrenheit 10.

Began the version of the 63d. Psalm. I went out this morning an hour before the meeting of the House. Left Cards at the lodgings of Coll. Drayton, and Mr Cambreleng— Then called at Mrs Blake’s where I saw Coll. Watmough, Genl. E. F. Chambers and Mr Shepherd. Mr Chambers was overset in a Stage, on his way hither from Baltimore, and much bruised, not so however as to confine him this day— My final call was at Fletcher’s where I saw Mr Grennell—the rest of the boarders there were all gone to the Capitol— I was then at the Meeting of the House— The Call of States for Petitions for Petitions and Resolutions was completed— This being the thirtieth day of the Session, after this Petitions will be called for only on Monday’s— There was no Committee of the whole, but the yeas and nays were twice taken, upon laying Resolutions upon the table, and in both cases they were so disposed of. Mr Bouldin called up one of his Resolutions, but the House refused to consider it— T. Newton shewed me a Resolution he had drawn up for referring to a Select Committee the question how the proceeds of the public Lands shall be disposed of
of after the extinguishment of the National debt— James K. Polk of Tennessee as Chairman of a Select Committee reported a Bill apportioning the Representation, of the several States of the Union, under the 5th. Census— It was referred to the Committee of the whole House on the State of the Union, and Mr Polk gave notice that he should call it up next Monday— Adjourned before three and I walked home with T Newton— Joseph Blunt spent part of the Evening here— My Cough and sore throat are distressing.
5. VI. Thursday

Finished the version of the 63d. and began that of the 64th. Psalm. I walked to the Capitol and attended the Committee on Manufactures at eleven this Morning— Dr Condict, Mr Findlay, Mr Dayan, and John S. Barbour were present— Henry Horn and J. T. H. Worthington absent— They had met at ten, misnotified by the boy—though I had given him a written notification to shew them; appointing the hour to meet at 11.— I read to them the answer of the Secretary of the Treasury to the Letter I had written him asking for information—and I proposed to them the question whether the remission of duties should be postponed till after the extinguishment of the National debt—and whether the whole debt should be paid off before the 3d of March 1833— I found opinions not at all matured or concurring on this subject— The opinion of Mr Condict and Mr Findlay was rather in favour of a considerable remission of duties immediately, Mr Barbour’s more decisively so and Mr Dayan wishing to proceed to a reduction of the Tariff without reference to that question— I read a Letter from Mr J. B. Brown, which had been put into my hands yesterday by Mr Davis. The Committee agreed to meet again next Monday Morning at eleven. Then adjourned and I entered the house just as the Speaker took the Chair. Sundry Resolutions were offered and Bills reported and read— The rule itself limiting the debates upon Resolutions to one hour was modified— The Bill for adjusting the claim of the State of South-Carolina was taken up, on the motion of Mr M’Coy to refer the Bill, and the Report of the Committee of Military Affairs, to the Committee of Claims. Mr M’Coy was not in the house, and I made a short speech in favour of the reference to the Committee of Claims, which brought up, M’Duffie, Speight, Everett, Burgess, Reed, J. Davis and Drayton against me— Lewis Williams alone supported me; and the motion for reference was rejected by a large majority— The question then came upon the Bill, but it was near four O’Clock, and the house adjourned— What shall I do upon the lesson of this day? The Committee on Manufactures do not agree with my principles with regard to the payment of the debt—a speech of ten minutes brings down upon me a swarm from all quarters of the house, among whom three members from my own State— What is it? as I was coming home I overtook Stevenson the Speaker, who told me I was unquestionably right upon the principle, and that twenty members had told him they would have voted with me, but that it would have seemed like casting an imputation upon the military Committee— Shall I not take warning from these Symptoms of universal opposition?— Shall I not feel that my prudence and my escape from utter ruin depends upon my abstaining from taking part in all debateable questions; and is this compatible with the duties of my Station?—
6. V. Friday.

Finished the version of the 64th. Psalm. A great change of weather has taken place, and a thaw commenced which carried off almost all the Snow— I rode to the Capitol Hill, and called upon General Adair, with whom 25 years since I sat in the Senate— He gave me now some of his opinions, which were in no wise congruous with my own. He thought this new manufacturing interest was more deeply injurious to the interests of New England—than to those of any other part of the Union. His argument was that the natural interest of New-England consisted of Commerce—shipping and navigation— That by diverting a large capital from these objects to manufactures, great numbers of young men were thrown out of employment and means of subsistence, and obliged to emigrate to the western States and Territories, where they were remarkable only for idleness profligacy, and dishonesty— This he had found in an extensive tour he had made last year, in the Western Country—where the young men who had emigrated from Kentucky, active and industrious young men, would come and give him this account of the Yankees— He also disapproved of Steam-boat Navigation upon the Western rivers; and said their produce sold at higher prices in Kentucky before the Steam-boat trade than now. That the only advantage they had derived from Steam-boats was that of ascending the river, in a shorter time and having foreign goods cheaper— But the accidents and disasters to property were much greater in the Steam-boats, than they had been in the flats— He had also a very poor opinion of the coasting trade, which was of no profit to the Nation, nothing being gained by it, and it never made Sailors good for anything— I said that might be true of the Coasters employed in river Navigation— He said it was the same thing with them all, and every officer of the Navy would tell you that Sailors from the Coasting trade were not worth having— He spoke also with contempt of the Mania for internal improvement, which he said was a raging disease throughout the Country— To all this I made no reply—except to the last observation. I said I was much affected with the disease myself.— But I thought I perceived anti-Clayism and anti yankeeism at the bottom of it all, and saw how those two Spirits were operating in Kentucky— In the House a Multitude of Resolutions was offered— Twelve bills upon private claims were passed in Committee of the whole, Mr Speight in the Chair, and reported to the House without Amendment. Mr Whittlesey proposed an Amendment to a Revolutionary Pensioners Bill, which raised a debate but the Amendment was rejected— E. Root started objections to all the Bills for giving pensions to individuals—but they were blasted down by a short speech from Philemon Thomas of Louisiana— Upon one Bill from the Committee of Commerce, a small grant to a Surveyor of the Customs at New-York, objection was made by Leonard Jarvis a member of the Committee, and before the question was taken the house about 3. O’Clock adjourned— Mr Appleton introduced me to P. Thomas the successor of Mr Gurley— I asked R. H. Wilde to dine with me to-morrow, but he declined on account of his health— I asked Mr Appleton for a copy of the Bill proposed at the Meeting the other Evening for the reduction of the Tariff—which he promised me— Mr Huntington of Connecticut gave me his Umbrella to walk home with; as it was raining— The change of weather disabled me for the Evening.
7. IV:15 Saturday.

Up, between two and three this Morning, and rose, shortly after four. Began the version of the 65th. Psalm— Wrote on the draft for a Report of the Committee on Manufactures; but what they will not sanction, and the substance of which I must therefore abandon or bring it forth in a new form— I walked round the Capitol Hill, and called twice at Dr Condict’s lodgings intending to read to him what I had written of the Report; but he was not at home— I called also at John W. Taylor’s to read it to him and take his advice: but he too was out— Walking round the Capitol Hill I overtook P. L. Tracy, who told me he had dined yesterday or the day before at the Presidents and that he was very feeble; and made an excuse for having the company and retiring— The thaw continues with some rain. I had a morning visit from R. Peters Reporter of the decisions of the U.S. Supreme Court— Their Session is to commence next Monday. But Judge M’lean is the only Member of the Court yet arrived— Peters said he had talked last Evening with Stevenson the Speaker, who told him that his reason for not appointing me chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations was that I was in no personal Relations with the President— We had the company above named to dine with us.— Mr Southard had told me yesterday that his health was indifferent and if the day should be bad he should ask me to excuse him and he did not come— Amory was in very high Spirits, and talked without ceasing to the great amusement of the Company— The Evening was gone before they retired so that I had no time to read or write.
8. VI:30. Sunday— Fahrenheit 30. Sleet and Rain.

I was up twice in the Night. First about one in the morning when I was awaked by my wife who was extremely ill; and had a very violent fainting fit— I went up to John Kirk, roused him from bed and ordered him to go for Doctor Huntt— But on returning below found Mrs Adams so much recovered that she declined having the Doctor sent for— About three there was a noise outside of the house, which seemed like an attempt to break open an outer door. I rose again, went below and examined all the doors and windows; and found all quiet— These incidents so disturbed my repose that it encroached upon the morning and I finally rose by daylight— I heard at the Presbyterian Church, Mr Smith from 1. John 3.20. [“]For if our heart condemn us, God is greater than our heart, and knoweth all things.”— Mr Smith’s discourse was a metaphysical analysis and deduction, comparing together self-condemnation as the less, and the condemnation of God as the greater— An unfortunate cause of numberless religious disputes is a want of precise definitions to words of the highest power— Mr Smith inveighed most learnedly against Sin— But what is Sin?—one of the Apostles says it is something exceedingly Sinful— But this is one definition— Mr Smith I think defines Sin, anything contrary to the Will of God—but this would require another definition— Mr Smith approached this day nearer than has been usual with him to the doctrines of original sin, total depravity and regeneration— The weather and walking were so bad, that there were very few persons at Church. Mr Smith gave notice that on the same account there would be no afternoon service— Nor was
there any at St. John’s Church— Mrs Adams was quite unwell the whole day; and in the afternoon sent for Dr Huntt— I answered two Letters received from Alexander Wilson Campbell.
9. IV. Monday.

Finished the version of the 65th. and began that of the 66th. Psalm; and I concluded the draft of a Report in part for the Committee of Manufactures. Mr D’Homergue called and told me that Mr Duponceau would be here this Evening or to-morrow. D’Homergue’s Bill is before the Committee of Agriculture of which General Root is Chairman— Root he says starts a question of the Constitutional power of Congress to make the appropriation— But Mr Jenifer a member of the Committee is a liberal man, and does not agree with him— He thinks a majority of the Committee will be for reporting the Bill— I walked to the Capitol and on approaching it overtook Mr Findlay a member of the Committee of Manufactures, who told me we had a Committee who never would agree upon any thing— Of this I had already a strong Suspicion. At the meeting of the Committee Findlay—Henry Horn and John S. Barbour were present. Dr Condict—Mr Dayan and Mr Worthington absent— I stated distinctly the question whether the Committee would proceed upon the basis of extinguishing the debt by the 4th. of March 1833 or not— Barbour met the question immediately— Findlay and Horn flew the course— I saw it was in vain to read the draft of a Report that I had made, and kept it in my pocket— Findlay said that the question about rechartering the Bank must be deferred till after the next Elections and they would all be decided by it.— The Committee agreed to meet at 1/2 past ten Wednesday Morning— In the House, I presented the petition of Frederick Rehorn of New-York referred to the Committee on Manufactures— M’Duffie presented a Memorial from the President and Directors of the Bank of the United States, praying for a renewal of their Charter, which led to a brisk debate till four O’Clock— The question was to what Committee the Memorial should be referred— The debate was finally arrested by the previous question—the Memorial committed to the Committee of Ways and Means, by yeas and nays 100 to 90.— Mr Connell and Joseph Blunt spent the Evening here— Mrs Adams very ill, confined to her bed—
10. V:30. Tuesday

Mr Lewis is a Member of the Society of Friends and has taken much part for the last twenty years in the measures leading to the abolition of Slavery. He came to have some conversation with me upon the subject of Slavery in the District of Columbia— I asked him if he had seen the remarks that I made on presenting the Petitions from Pennsylvania— He said he had— But wished to know my Sentiments upon Slavery— I told him I thought they did not materially differ from his own— I abhorred Slavery; did not suffer it in my family, and felt proud of belonging to the only State in the Union, which at the first census of population in 1790 had returned in the column of Slaves—none—that in presenting the petitions I had expressed the wish that the subject might not be discussed in the house— Because I believed discussion would lead to ill-will—to heart-burnings, to mutual hatred, where the first of wants was harmony, and without accomplishing anything else— I asked him what he should think of the Inhabitants of the District of Columbia, if they should petition the Legislature of Pennsylvania to enact a Law, to compel all the Citizens of that State to bear arms in defence of their Country? He said he should think they were meddling with what did not concern them— I said the People of the District of Columbia, might say the same of Citizens of Pennsylvania, petitioning for the abolition of Slavery, not in
that State itself but in the District of Columbia— He said there were many persons of that opinion, and he had been very desirous of distinctly knowing what my Sentiments upon the subject were— At the House—I received and presented to the House a Petition, for a Pension which was referred to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions— Resolutions and Petitions were called for Bates Cooke made a long Speech on the Niagara frontier claims—arrested by the expiration of the hour— Polk of Tennessee called up the Bill for the Apportionment of Representation, under the 5th census— It was referred to a Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Michael Hoffman in the Chair— The Bill was reported with the ratio of representation fixed at 48,000. a motion was made by Robert Craig of Virginia to strike out 48,000 without proposing to insert any other number— This gave rise to a long debate on a point of order which grew into a snarl till near four O’Clock when the house adjourned. Walking down the avenue with Richard M. Johnson, he spoke of the vehement attack upon me, made by Tristam Burges and three of my Colleagues last Thursday. Mr Johnson after his manner stimulated me to answer and I told him I thought I should. I was all this Evening writing— Mrs Adams is better but keeps her chamber.
11. V. Wednesday.

I met the Committee on Manufactures at 1/2 past ten— Overtook and walked with Dr Condict. Told him I had called at his lodgings twice last Saturday to read to him, my draft of a Report in part for the Committee on Manufactures— In the Committee we had much conversation and a total disagreement on all sides— Dr Condict was for an immediate and total repeal of duties on the unprotected Articles— A majority of the Committee were for returning a small duty on all Articles— We began with Appleton’s draft of a Bill Question upon Teas—Bohea—Souchong—Hyson, S. . .n—Young Hyson and Gunpowder 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. Cents a pound. Our time expired, and we agreed to meet at 1/2 past ten next Monday.— In the House Bates Cook finished his Speech on the Niagara frontier claims— Answered by E. Whittlesey— Reference to the Committee of Claims— After some attempt by Wickliffe, to get the Rules suspended Polk called up the apportionment Bill— No Quorum— Motion to adjourn Negatived— Call of the House, suspended. New attempt to take up the apportionment Bill—no Quorum— Polk gave up the attempt— Several engrossed Bills were passed—among the rest a Bill for granting pensions of 8 dollars a month to Elisha James and Nathaniel Standish— Mr Hubbard, Chairman of the Revolutionary Pension Committee said to me, that I must ask some friend to attend to it in the Senate— Dearborn and I. C. Bates spoke to me of the Ratio of Representation of 48000— They preferred 46 or 44000. The last would not diminish the numbers of Representatives of any one State. I asked Coll R. M. Johnson, if he had the petition of the Officers who had styled the last War, the second War of Independence. He said he had, and would send it to me— I invited Genl. Root, Genl. Pitcher and T. R. Mitchell of South Carolina to dine with me next Saturday. They promised to come—Verplanck was engaged— The House adjourned about two. Half the members were gone to hear Mr Clay speak on his Resolution for the repeal of duties. I had a visit before dinner from R. H. Wilde, and after dinner from R. M. Maury now residing at Norfolk. Mrs Adams still keeps her chamber.
12. V:30. Thursday

Mrs Adams was very unwell in the Night, and up more than two hours before I rose— I finished the version of the 66th. and began that of the 67th. Psalm— Mr Letcher of Kentucky introduced to me two citizens of that State, Mr Morehead and Mr Pope a Cousin of Mr John Pope the Governor of Arkansas— I called at Gadsby’s and enquired for Mr Silsbee, Mr Webster and Mr Duponceau of Philadelphia, who had called at our house yesterday— They were all out— I went in to the Senate chamber, and gave Mr Silsbee a minute of the Bill which passed the house of Representatives yesterday—granting pensions to Elisha James and Nathaniel Standish—to which he promised his attention— I found much excitement among the Senators from the South, upon the doctrines of Mr Clay’s Speech of yesterday— Mr Tyler of Virginia, and Genl. S. Smith of Maryland spoke of dividing the Union by the Potowmack— In the House the Consideration of a Resolution offered by Mr Bouldin, about minimum and ad valorem duties was called up and Bouldin Jarvis asked for the yeas and nays— The proposition was to refer the enquiry to the Committee of Commerce— Andrew Stewart moved to amend by referring to the Committee on Manufactures—and the debate continued till the expiration of the hour— James K. Polk moved to take up the orders of the day— The Census apportionment Bill was taken up and discussed till past 3 O’Clock in Committee of the whole, without making any progress and the Committee rose— J. W. Taylor told me that there had been an opposition Caucus last Evening, at Vance’s lodgings—and there had been one meeting before which Edward Everett had attended as he did that of last Evening— One member from each delegation had been chosen to consult the respective delegations, and the question was upon the adoption of an opposition course of policy— To canvass all the measures of the Administration and determine on a concert of opposition movements— This is I suppose not a new mode of procedure— It was undoubtedly followed during the last Administration— Nothing has yet been determined upon— Mrs Adams keeps her chamber— John dined at Mr Frye’s— Mrs Nowlan came home—
13. V:15. Friday

Finished the version of the 67th. and began that of the 68th. Psalm—much dissatisfied with myself but I must go on— I called at the War Office, and left with Mr Cass the Secretary the papers of Jacob Loring’s claim for a Revolutionary Pension—to ascertain if they were sufficient to entitle the claimant to a Pension by the existing Rules of Law, or whether the application must be made to Congress— He said he would cause examination to be made of the papers and let me know— I told him that Isaac Hull Adams wished to obtain admission as a Cadet at West Point— He asked if I knew whether there was a Cadet at the Academy from the District represented by me— I did not know, but told him that Quincy the place of my residence was not in the County of Plymouth which was my district— He asked the age of the applicant, and I told him he was in his twentieth year—he said he should have the warrant of admission for next June— I attended at the House. Bouldin’s second Resolutions were discussed on the question of reference whether to the Committee of Commerce or of Manufactures— Some sharp debate between C. C. Cambreleng and J. Davis— The hour expired. Fridays and Saturdays are by Rule devoted to the consideration of private claims— Polk moved to suspend the Rule and take up the apportionment Bill— Vote 94 to 56. But as the rule to be suspended required a majority of two thirds the motion failed— Twelve private Bills were referred to the Committee of the whole G. M’Duffie Chairman— A debate arose upon the third of the Bills a Revolutionary pensioners bill which continued till 1/2 past 3. O’Clock. The
Committee rose; reported two bills without amendment and progress made in the third— Dearborn proposed to offer a Resolution to adjourn over till Monday— Objection made and Dearborn moved to suspend the rule— It was suspended and Dearborn offered his Resolution. Whittlesey asked for the yeas and nays— They were declared 105 to 75— R. B. Maury called me out to ask me to speak to I. C. Bates of the Committee on Revolutionary pensions in behalf of a petition of Mr Brook of Georgetown— J. Connell called me out to ask me to offer a Resolution to authorise the investment at interest of monies now in the Treasury paid by the Danish Government for the Satisfaction of Claims, but which for a year or more cannot be paid to the claimants— He said he would write to me, and call to see me to-morrow on the subject— C. C. Cambreleng gave me a Letter to him concerning a manufacturing interest. The Meeting to form a Temperance Society was held this Evening in the Hall of the House of Representatives— I attended late—near 8 O’Clock. Mr Cass, the Secretary of War was the Chairman— He drinks nothing but water and is dying of dyspepsy. Mr Felix Grundy was closing a Speech as I entered the Hall, which was excessively crowded particularly with Ladies— Mr Frelinghuysen—Mr I. C. Bates, Mr Wayne of Georgia and Mr D. Webster made Speeches and offered Resolutions except Mr Bates, who had lost his— There was an impertinent intrusion, by some Stranger, who proposed another Meeting at the same place next Monday Evening to form an antifashionable Society. The Speeches were all commendably short, and of course bore some resemblance to preaching— I spoke to Mr Bates about the petition of Mr Brook, as I had promised Mr Maury. General Macomb came partly home with me with the Carriage, but alighted opposite to the State Department— As to Temperance Societies and Addresses how can one speaking on such a Subject avoid common place— What so easy as a Sermon against drunkenness What so hard as to say what has not been said a thousand times before? I cannot speak upon any commended theme.
14. V:30. Saturday.

Mr Connell called this Morning and conversed with me upon his project for investing at interest the sums paid by the Danish Government for claims, until it can be paid to the claimants. I had received a Letter from him concerning it yesterday; with a printed copy of the Convention with Denmark— I advised him first to see the Secretary of the Treasury and ascertain whether it could not be done without requiring the action of the Legislature; and next to ascertain what the Bank of the United States would allow for interest on the deposit— I said that of course if the authority of Congress should be required to sanction the arrangement it would be on the condition that the deposit should be held at the risk of the Claimants— Mr Connell said he would immediately see the Secretary of the Treasury. Mr Ohl brought a Letter of Introduction from John Burns— He is a German Merchant of Philadelphia— He has a claim before Congress for a drawback upon sugars, and will see me again with documents and vouchers— I called upon the Secretary of the Treasury and had a long conversation with him upon the Modification of the Tariff; the payment of the debt the Manufactures, and the question as to rechartering the Bank of the United States.
He said he had received no answers to the Letters of enquiry which he had addressed in various quarters upon receiving mine— I told him that my impression had been very strong, in favour of the President’s project and his plan for paying off the National debt by the 3d. of March 1833. but I had not found a single other person in Congress, favourable to that measure— And especially none willing to effect it by selling the seven Millions of public Bank Stock for eight— It is impossible for me to enter into the details of our Conversation— He had calculations to shew that the Bank Stock might be sold to pay off the three per Cents, not only without loss, but with profit to the Public—which supposing the Stock to be sold at eight Millions, were calculations to prove that five and two make three— I could not abide them— He said the Directors of this Bank were willing to take eight Millions for the Stock, without a pledge, but with the chance of a new Charter— I thought it would either be a fraudulent or a foolish bargain on our part— He said the Bank would give twelve Millions for the seven of Stock; with a pledge of a new Charter— And he agreed that the Treasury Department could not go on for a single year without the Bank— I told him I had prepared a Resolution, for bringing to issue in the House of Representatives the question of rechartering the Bank, when the Memorial from the President and Directors relieved me from the necessity of offering it. He made several remarks upon Mr Clay’s speech the other day in the Senate, which he charged with being in many respects erroneous; and he read me an act relating to the sinking fund passed in 1830 which he thought would make it positively obligatory on the Government to pay off several Millions of the three per Cent Stocks the present year— He said he would write me another Letter stating that he had not yet collected the information which the Committee had requested— He wished also another call to be made on him in the shape of a Resolution of the house, of which he promised to send me a private Note— I returned the visits of Thomas F. Foster and Henry G. Lamar members of the House of Representatives from Georgia— Mrs Lamar was there and Mr and Mrs P. L. Tracy were visiting her— W. T. Nuckolls of South-Carolina, and Charles C. Johnson of Virginia came in while I was there. We had a company of eleven to dine with us— T. R. Mitchell of South-Carolina and Lewis Williams of North-Carolina had accepted but sent excuses this morning. Mrs Adams was too unwell to come down, and we had no Ladies at the Table.
15. IV. Sunday.

In the Morning I heard at the Presbyterian Church Mr Smith from 1. Thessalonians 2.20 “For ye are our glory and joy”—and in the afternoon from Mark 13:33. “Take ye heed—watch and pray, for ye know not when the time is.” The duty of religious caution— In the afternoon Mr and Mrs W. Lee were in the pew. Mr J. B. Brown, and Peter H. Schenk, deputies I suppose from the New York Tariff Convention called here while I was at Church and Joseph Blunt was here in the Evening. Intending to leave the City for New-York on Tuesday— Brought up my Diary, and answered two Letters from W. S. Wait of Boston— Received a proof Sheet of Indian History from T. L. M’Kenney, and undertook to revise it, for which I found myself unable— The multiplication of business to which my attention is called distracts me— I now receive almost every day five or six Letters—upon subjects of inexhaustible variety, and among them scarcely one in a week of the least utility to any one but the writer— Every one opens the correspondence for purposes of his own—and if the answer is delay there comes a second peevish or petulant complaint of neglect.
I answered two Letters of William S. Wait, and had many others which I was obliged to postpone— Overpowered by drowsiness.
16. VI. Monday

Walking to the House of Representatives I overtook Joseph Blunt and met Edward Wyer. Blunt was in great concern, having heard that his father had been overset in a Stage near Zanesville, and was seriously hurt— He talked of going off in the Western Stage this afternoon. In the House, the States were successively called for Petitions— I presented one from Joshua Eddy for restoration to a Revolutionary Pension; which was referred to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions— One of William Callender for some invention in the Art of Gunnery— Referred to the Committee on Military Affairs— One from Inhabitants of Pennsylvania, for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave Trade in the District of Columbia, which was laid on the Table— And having no Petition in the case of Jacob Loring I offered a Resolution to instruct the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions to enquire into the expediency of placing his name on the Pension-List; and the Resolution, and the papers were referred to the Committee— After the Petitions were presented, and several Bills were reported Mr Bouldin’s Resolution, with the amendment proposed by J. Davis was taken up— Mr Davis made a Speech of about one hour in answer to Cambreleng; to which the latter replied, aided by Mr Bouldin himself; both to very little effect— Davis’s speech was of great power—severe and bitter—but not exceeding the bounds of decorum— The House adjourned at 3. O’Clock.— There had been little more than a Quorum all day; many members being in the Senate-chamber to hear Mr Hayne’s answer to Mr Clay’s Speech of last Thursday— Walking home I met Joseph Blunt again; and J. Sergeant who is here attending the Supreme Court— I received Several Letters— Among the rest one from E. C. Purdy, Editor of a Newspaper at Lowell: enclosing two Papers in one of which is an article of attack upon me— Mr J. B. Brown, and Mr Peter H. Schenk, manufacturers and members of the Tariff convention late at New-York came and spent the Evening here—in Conversation upon the subject of the manufacturing interest wool and woollens—Frauds on the Revenue—Minimums—Ad valorem duties, and value of the Pound Sterling— I shall see them again.
17. V:15. Tuesday.

Mr Fendall called upon me this morning; but his visit was short. I was obliged to go up to the Capitol, and met the Committee on Manufactures at 1/2 past ten— Dr Condict—Findlay—Worthington and Barbour were there— Mr Dayan came in late— H. Horn was absent— I read the Letter yesterday received from the Secretary of the Treasury, and his draft of a Resolution with his private note to me mentioning that Mr M’Duffie would offer a similar Resolution— He did offer it yesterday and upon a comparison of the Resolution offered by him our Committee were of opinion that the Committee of Ways and Means were encroaching upon our functions; and I was instructed when M’Duffie’s Amendment should be taken up in the house, to move our Resolution as an Amendment to his— So that the House may come to a determination which of the Committees shall undertake the reduction of the Tariff— We did nothing more— Dr Condict wished to strike out the words—after the payment of the National debt. J. S. Barbour supported him—but Findlay, Worthington and Dayan voted against it, and the words were retained. In the House, a few Petitions, and Resolutions were offered with unanimous
consent— Then Mr Bouldin’s Resolution of Enquiry was taken up with A. Stewart’s Amendment, which he withdrew, and for which that of J. Davis was substituted. Mr Stewart occupied the hour with a Speech, and was then stopp’d by a motion of Mr Polk to pass to the orders of the day— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. M Hoffman in the Chair— The question was at last taken separately on striking out 48000, to make a blank and rejected— Mr Hubbard then proposed to strike out 48000 and insert 44000. which he supported by a short Speech— The house were extremely impatient for the question but I stated in a few words the reasons of my objection to the number 48000 and of my preference for 44000—and this gave rise to a new debate— Mercer, Carson, Polk, Jenifer took part in it and Mr Wayne moved the Committee should rise to adjourn the debate. After the House resumed, Mr Wickliffe, by dint of importunity and perseverance got the rule suspended, and a bill through to the third reading— Adjourned at near four O’Clock.

Finished the version of the 68th. Psalm—one of those which I have found of excessive difficulty— Full of difficulties in the Common Bible; and through which I have been obliged to drive blindfold— Mr Tracy of New-York called upon me with Messrs Heister and Potts members of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania: In the House the day began as usual with several Resolutions of enquiry offered considered and adopted by unanimous consent of the House— Members start up every morning one after another and offer such Resolutions till some member gets impatient and objects— Mr Bouldin’s Resolution was then taken up— Stewart finished his Speech and withdrew his Amendment. Davis then offered his Amendment— But Wickliffe moved the previous Question, which arrested all amendments and came to the point whether the question should be taken upon Bouldin’s Resolution, as originally offered— The previous question is—“shall the main question be now put upon a count[”] there appeared 96 for and 77. against it—but an appeal was made to take the question by yea’s and nay’s—upon which the yeas were 93. nays 96— So that the same question, which had first been carried by a majority of 19. was on the application of the test lost by a majority of three— The resolution remains for further consideration— The apportionment Bill was then taken up— Allan of Kentucky Le Compte, P. L. Tracy, Burd, Clay of Alabama, Ellsworth, Grennell and Thomas of Louisiana, spoke, also Dearborn, Reed and Bates of Massachusetts. Briggs moved the Committee should rise and the House adjourned at 1/2 past 3— Mr Sergeant spent part of the Evening here— I was so deeply engaged that I neglected this diary.
19. IV. Thursday

Began the Version of the 69th. Psalm, but my mind was labouring with other meditations, and the numbers came heavy and sulky— At 1/2 past ten I attended the Committee on Manufactures and read some papers which had been referred to the Committee— Present Dr Condict—Findlay—Worthington and Horn. absent Dayan and J. S. Barbour— I was instructed, to offer the Resolution sent from the Treasury Department, and to ask a suspension of the Rule, by which such Resolutions are required to lay over one day, and that it should be immediately be considered— I did accordingly offer the Resolution, and the House agreed immediately to consider it— M’Duffie Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means then moved to lay it on the Table, alledging that he had offered some days since a Resolution to the same effect, which ought to have precedence of mine— But he found the house would not sustain him, and asked that the two Resolutions should be considered together— I said I had no objection to the Houses considering
his Resolution immediately after they should have decided upon mine but I could not consent that they should be taken up together. Mr Carson of North-Carolina moved an Amendment to my Resolution, requiring the Secretary of the Treasury in his plan of Tariff to reduce the duties to the necessary wants of the Government— But he soon saw the house would not sustain him in that, and withdrew his amendment— Dr Condict had moved in Committee an Amendment to strike out the words “after the payment of the public debt” but Findlay, Worthington and Horn, voted against it. He renewed the motion in the house and it was carried without opposition— There was a blank to fill which was filled with the fiscal year 1831— The Resolution was adopted, and that offered by Mr M’Duffie, immediately afterwards— There was some debate upon a bill authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to make some composition with a broken Bank of Erie— Postponed till Tuesday— The apportionment Bill, was again taken up in the house, and speeches were made by Briggs, Allan, Polk, Carson, R. M. Johnson, and some others— Mr Wayne, who has announced for several days his intention to make a speech on this question, moved that the Committee should vote after three. They rose accordingly and the house adjourned— J. Connell was here this Evening. He is in great concern for the convoy cases, before the danish Commission, now in Session.
20. IV:30. Friday.

Morning and Evening waste away in the variety of my occupations so that nothing is done well— At the House— Friday’s and Saturday’s are devoted to private Bills— A few Resolutions by unanimous consent were offered; but they were soon arrested— Bouldin’s Resolution with Preamble was resumed, and T. R. Mitchell of South-Carolina, made an Anti-Tariff Speech— It was arrested by the expiration of the hour— Mr Polk moved to suspend the rule of transacting private business to take up the apportionment Bill, but it failed— Davis had modified his proposed amendment to Bouldins Resolution— The House went into Committee of the whole, Mr M’Duffie in the Chair, on fourteen private Bills—unfinished business of last Friday— There was no further debate upon the Bill granting a pension to D. Sizer which had occupied a great part of last Friday—but the Bill was reported to the House without amendment. There was a Bill for the Relief of the legal Representatives of David Dardin for a horse taken in the Revolutionary War. The Committee now proposed to give 1500 dollars for this horse and interest from 1780. till the final payment of the Revolutionary War debt. Mr Whittlesey moved to strike out the interest— Root made a speech against the Bill, and said he had known this claim to be good for nothing thirty years ago: and the horse Romulus had been prancing about this hall from that day to this— Bouldin, who from the committee on Revolutionary claims had reported the Bill defended it and Mark Alexander of Virginia made a short speech in its favour, but the interest was struck out.— The Bills were then reported to the House— Mitchell asked for the yeas ad nays upon the Bill for Sizer— Hoffman made a warm speech against the Bill, on the ground that there should be a general Bill; but the vote was more than two to one to pass the Bill for Sizer— The yeas and nays, were also taken upon striking out the interest in the Dardin Bill, and carried by a like majority— Then the yeas and nays were called for and ordered on the passage of the Bill, but before they were taken an adjournment was moved and carried.
The Speaker this Morning presented a Memorial, which he said he had received from the President and Directors of the Bank of Pennsylvania, touching the re-chartering of the Bank of the United States— One of the Anti-Bankers thinking it was a remonstrance against the re-charter called for the reading of the Memorial— It was a very earnest, and able argument for the recharter. The Anti-bankers attempted several times to stop the reading but failed— Wickcliffe moved an Instruction of enquiry to go with the Memorial to the Committee, which was adopted— Edward Everett had been absent from his Seat yesterday from indisposition— He was in it this morning but soon went away apparently very un-well. Coll. James Thomas spent the early part of the Evening here— River open.
21. IV:30. Saturday

Attended the Committee on Manufactures at half past ten—Dr Condict, Findlay, Horn, Worthington, and Dayan were present— John S. Barbour absent. J. B. Brown and P. H. Schenk, attended the Committee, and gave much miscellaneous information, similar to that which they had given me last Monday Evening— Committee adjourned to meet at 1/2 past ten Monday Morning. Mr Schenks information was chiefly relating to frauds upon the Revenue in the importation of Wool and Woollens at New-York. In the House the day was consumed in debate upon Mr Bouldin’s Resolution, and J. Davis’s Amendment— T. R. Mitchell finished his speech— An attempt was made at the expiration of the hour to pass to the orders of the day, but the House refused to go into them. Appleton, M’Duffie, Cambreleng, Carson, Huntington, Hoffman and Bouldin all made tart speeches— J. W. Taylor asked a division of the question, and that the vote should first be taken on striking out—and then the previous question was called for by yeas and nays—and was carried— I voted against the striking out, but it was carried by a majority ofThen the question came upon Davis’s Amendment— Stewart moved an amendment upon it, and Nuckolls an Amendment upon that— The previous question was called again and carried; but before the main question was put, an adjournment was moved and carried— It had two or three times before been moved and lost. It was just 4. when the house adjourned— A notice was sent round to the delegations from Massachusetts and Maine to meet Monday Morning at ten in the Committee room of the Committee of Commerce— Mrs Stewart had written me a note this Morning requesting me to call on her this afternoon. I went immediately after my return from the house— She enquired for a number of her late brothers Letters which she thought I had not returned— I told her I believed I had returned all that I had ever received: but that on my return to Quincy I would make further search and if I should find any more of his manuscripts would not fail to return them. She seemed to be much concerned about them, and also about some poetry which she said was with them— We had company to dine, chiefly members of Congress— I received a Letter from Governor Levi Lincoln with a printed copy of his Message to the Legislature. Several other Letters also which I have now no time to answer— Card visits from Messrs de Beaumont and Tocqueville.
22. IV: 30. Sunday.

Heard Mr Smith at the Second Presbyterian Church, in the morning from John 12.36. “While ye have light, believe in the light, that ye may be the children of light.” The doctrine was the duty of giving to Religion, a suitable reception. After the morning Service I left Cards at Bernards Hotel for Messrs de Beaumont and de Tocqueville, and afterwards called upon the Judges of the Supreme Court, who are lodging at Mr T. Ringgold’s— I saw Chief Justice
Marshall, and the Judges Duval, Story and Thompson— The Chief Justice said he was well, but looks more declining than he was when I saw him in November at Philadelphia— Story has also been ill with a bilious Colic— Mr Smiths afternoon text was from Acts 3.26. [“]Unto you first, God having raised up his Son Jesus, sent him to bless you, in turning away every one of you from his iniquities”— An evening of painful and tedious drudgery—as well as of sharp anxiety— Judge Baldwin lodges with the rest of the Court at Ringgold’s, but I did not see him— Judge M’lean lodges at his Son in Law Weeds, and Judge Johnson is ill, at home in South-Carolina.
23. IV:30. Monday

Attended at the Committee-room of the Committee of Commerce of the House of Representatives at ten O’Clock this Morning a Meeting of the Delegations of Massachusetts and Maine, called by Mr Davis who is the Agent appointed by the Governor of Massachusetts for the claim. It was to propose a Resolution to be introduced either into the Senate or the House to call upon the Secretary of War, for a report whether upon the principles on which the accounts of Massachusetts have been adjusted, there is not more due than has been paid— Davis says there is and that he proposes this course of proceeding by concert with the Secretary of War— It was referred to the Senators from the two States jointly with Mr Davis— J. Reed was chairman of the Meeting. I then attended the Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures— Present: Messrs. Condict, Findlay, Horn, Dayan and Worthington— Absent J. S. Barbour— Messrs. J. B. Brown and P. H. Schenk, were there, and gave further information respecting the frauds on the Revenue, at New-York, especially upon the importation of Woollen Manufactures. They said there were also great frauds upon Iron— Mr Schenk left with me two Letters and a short pamphlet for the use of the Committee— In the house; there was the usual weekly call for Petitions— Coll. Drayton presented a Memorial from the Members of the South Carolina Legislature opposed to nullification, against the Tariff a debate immediately arose, to which of the standing Committees it should be referred. The Ways and Means or the Manufactures. It was finally returned to the Committee of Ways and Means. Mr Davis’s Amendment to Mr Bouldin’s Resolution was taken up. It had been determined on Saturday that the previous question should be put. It was taken by yeas and nays and decided in the affirmative— Stewart’s and Nuckolls’s Amendments were thus set aside— After the previous question had been decided, R. H. Wilde moved to lay the amendment on the Table. The Speaker declared this to be out of order— Wilde then moved a call of the House— There were sixty or seventy members absent in the Senate chamber, hearing Mahlon Dickerson descant upon the Tariff and gallanting the Ladies— Many of them came in while the roll was calling, and when about half through the call was suspended— The Resolution was carried by a vote of 127 to 51— I voted against it as an unnecessary complication of the labours of the Committee— When the previous Question is called there are three successive questions put—1st. Shall the previous question be put if the house so decide then 2. The previous question itself, which is Shall the main question now be put? and if so—then 3. The main question itself, stripped of all amendments— But the house may decide 1. not to put the previous question—
2 Not to put the main question— The Speaker considers the first decision of the house, as only seconding the motion for taking the previous question— These debates and votes had consumed the day, and it was near four when the house adjourned. Mr D’Homergue spent the Evening here; and conversed much upon Silks
24. V. Tuesday.

I finished yesterday the version of the 69th Psalm, and made this morning that of the 70th. Morning visit from Mr Niles; with whom I had some conversation upon the Anti-Tariff pamphlet exposition which I received two or three days since— Niles stoutly denies the truth of most of the pamphleteers Statements— As it rained I rode to the Capitol— In the House Mr Jenifer’s Resolution proposing a Committee to enquire into the expediency of making an appropriation for colonizing the free people of colour— Alexander of Virginia moved it should be laid on the table and Thompson of Georgia called for the yeas and nays thereon. The house by a vote of 104 to 71. refused to lay the Resolution on the Table— Mr Jenifer then made a Speech in support of his Resolution and Richard Coke junr. of Virginia made a Speech against it— The Hour expired and the apportionment Bill was taken up— Mr Wayne of Georgia made a speech of two hours in favour of the ratio of 44000. and left it unfinished— He spread the argument over too broad a surface and introduced a question complicating as I thought the subject beyond all necessity— It was to maintain that every State having a fraction of more than 30,000 was entitled to a Representative for that fraction. And he insisted that the veto of President Washington upon the first Apportionment Bill did not contravene that position. The Committee rose and the house adjourned about four. T. R. Mitchell brought me a Charleston Mercury, containing a Letter from this place, referring to a declaration which I made to the Committee of Manufactures that the adjustment of the Tariff ought to be a matter of compromise, but the Letter represents me as having taken the Southern side of the question, which I told Mitchell was not correct— J. Davis brought me another of the same papers, containing the Article— I shall hear enough reverberation of it from the North— When I came home, I found a copy of that paper had been sent to me with that Article marked— It is the Charleston Mercury of the 18th. There was a light rain all day, and I rode to and from the Capitol— In the Evening I received a Note from Mr Webster, enquiring concerning a point of fact in the Colonial trade question with Great Britain, which I answered— Also a note from Mr Knight to withdraw a Letter which he wrote me some days since, requesting me to offer to the House a Resolution for erecting a Monument over the grave of General Brown— I returned the Letter. I lose much of the Evening by drowsiness.
25. V. Wednesday. Snow-Storm.

I called this morning on Mr M’Lane at the Treasury Department, and conversed with him respecting the Resolution of the house calling upon him for information respecting the operation of the Tariff, and for a plan of reduction of the duties— He had written me a private note; saying that he would appoint any person whom I should recommend as an Agent to collect information; I said I had no person to recommend— He proposed that I should consult with Mr Appleton, and Mr Davis on the subject. I told him I believed the reduction of the Tariff must be a matter of compromise— Something must be given up on both sides— There was so little of that Spirit on either side, that I had scarcely a hope of effecting anything; but that I believed that the plan of reduction ought to come from the Treasury Department, and I for one should be disposed to give to such plan every
aid in my power; so far as should be consistent with my duties— I should certainly not consent to sacrifice the manufacturing interest— But something of concession would be due from that interest to appease the discontents of the South— He concurred altogether with these opinions, and I told him I would soon see him again— On my way to the Capitol I called upon Mr Webster—and gave him my recollections with regard to the question in his note which I had received last Evening— I gave him a rapid sketch of the history of the Colonial Trade question with Great Britain, and referred him specially to the Instruction from President Washington to Gouverneur Morris in October 1789— He said that was sufficient, and that he believed there would be a public discussion of the question in the Senate hereafter. In the House, there was a Call by States for Resolutions, but they were all postponed and the apportionment Bill was taken up.— Mr Wayne finished his Speech— He was followed by Hunt of Vermont on the same side, Bell of Tennessee, Patton of Virginia, and Polk on the other side M’Duffie pressed for the question to take up the appropriation Bills— Hubbard of New-Hampshire, who moved for the ration of 44000—moved an adjournment till to-morrow to give him an opportunity of reply, but the Committee refused to rise— Hubbard declined addressing the Committee further and said he would reply in the house— The Vote was taken by Tellers against striking out 48000 for 44000 by 105 to 81. Howard then moved as an Amendment that the new Apportionment should take effect not on the 3d. but the 6th. of March—so as to leave the Presidential election, and that of the next Congress to the present apportionment, upon which the Committee rose and the house adjourned. I took Mr Newton home to his lodgings— Snow afternoon and Evening— Began Psalm 71.
26. V:30. Thursday— Fahrenheit 0.

The Snow subsided late last Evening and this morning at Sunrise the thermometer was at 0 the Potowmac river which had opened froze over the second time— Mr Heman Lincoln of Boston called upon me, and rode with me to the Capitol— Attended the Committee on Manufactures—Condict, Horn, Dayan, Worthington and Barbour were present. Findlay absent— I read the two Resolutions of Inquiry passed by the House, and took the directions of the Committee to send copies of them to the Secretary of the Treasury and ask for the information from him— Adjourned to meet again Saturday Morning— In the House— The States were called over for Resolutions. The apportionment bill was taken up in Committee of the whole. Howard made his Speech, for postponing the operation of the new apportionment, till after the next Presidential and Congressional Elections— He met no support— Armstrong of Pennsylvania—Kerr, Craig, Polk, Beardsley spoke successively against it, till at last M’Duffie rose and begged that Gentlemen would make no more Speeches on that side— If there was another member in the house who thought with the mover of the Amendment he should be happy to hear him, but as it was very apparent there would not be ten votes in the house to sustain the motion it was to be hoped nothing more would be said against it— Howard was more abashed with this short Speech than by all the arguments against him, and withdrew his Motion— J. W. Taylor then moved 59000—lost then 53000 lost— Craig moved 51000—lost— Letcher of Kentucky moved 47000—lost— 46000 was also lost— The Bill was then reported to the House without Amendment— Wickcliffe moved that it should be recommitted to a select Committee of one member from each
State, with Instructions to strike out 48000. and leave the number in blank. The house then adjourned about four. I took home Coll. Drayton, Mr Cambreleng and Mr Everett— Mrs White of Florida had invited us to a party this Evening which we declined. Mr White urged me much this morning to go, but we have declined all attendance at Evening parties— The thermometer was no part of this day above 8— The nomination of Martin Van Buren as Minister to London was rejected yesterday by the casting vote of Vice-President Calhoun—23 and 23. Prentiss of Vermont and Bibb of Kentucky absent— I went into the Hall where the Supreme Court were sitting this Morning, and asked John Sergeant and R. Peters to dine with us on Saturday.
27. IV:30 Friday— Fahrenheit—4.

Extremity of Winter cold at Washington— It roused me with severe cramp in my legs about four this morning and I soon after rose— From the severity of the weather I rode up to the House— Friday’s and Saturday’s are assigned to the consideration of private claims— Mr Polk made an effort to suspend the rule for this day to take up the apportionment Bill, but a majority of two thirds was necessary to carry the motion and it failed by only three or four votes. Jenifer’s Resolution for making an appropriation to colonize the free People of Colour was taken up. He moved it should be postponed till Monday— Boon of Indiana moved it should be postponed to the second Monday in December. The question was debated till the hour had expired and the orders of the day were called for— The Bill for carrying into effect a commercial arrangement with the Republic of Colombia was taken up at the third reading and an additional Section—introduced in it. Wickliffe asked if there was a Republic of Colombia— Archer, the Chairman of the Committee of foreign relations answered rather confusedly, admitting that there was no such Republic but still insisting upon the passage of the Bill— I followed Mr Wickliffe’s enquiry with others which brought upon me besides Archer, E. Everett and Cambreleng, and the Bill passed by a large majority— The Bill for David Dardin’s heirs followed— Mr Claiborne of Virginia made a sort of mock heroic Speech about half an hour long in its favour— Mr Root spoke again shortly against it— Whittlesey produced in a folio Volume of Manuscript Reports from the Committee of Claims, a Report made in 1810 by Root as Chairman of the Committee of Claims in its favour, but Root explained that the Report was drawn up by Gholson of Virginia— That he Root reported it as Chairman of the Committee, but was against it himself— The Committee being divided 4 and 3. It appeared that Root had voted for it in the house. Dearborn made a short Speech in its favour. Said he had heard in the Gallery 25 years ago a very eloquent Speech in its favour and had then been fully impressed that it was just— The question was now taken by yeas and nays and the Bill passed 124 to 46— The claim was good for nothing; but any opposition from me would have been as fruitless as it was from Root— I barely recorded my vote against it. By suspending the Rule, the House got to and carried a vote to adjourn over till Monday. Then they resolved to call for Resolutions by States— Thirty or forty Resolutions were offered and passed— Nuckolls offered one to make his enquiries of the Committee of Manufactures to which Arnold of Tennessee objected that he did not like to see a Resolution so smuggled in, but it passed 63 to 57. Le Compte offered a Resolution that the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to enquire and Report upon the expediency of an Amendment to the Constitution to make the Judges of the Supreme and other Courts of the United States hold their offices for a term of years— This was superseded by a motion to adjourn, about
four O’Clock—there was then hardly a Quorum in the house to vote— I saw then the unfair advantage which the assiduous and the diligent sometimes take of the careless and the negligent— Gulian C. Verplanck told me he had received the free-trade Memorial, from Mr Gallatin and should present it on Monday to the House That Mr Gallatin wrote him it was too long— Mr Brown and Mr Schenk, spent part of the Evening with me— Conversing chiefly upon the frauds on the Revenue in the importations of Woolens. Mr Schenk goes off to-morrow to return to New York. Mr Brown is to remain here— They have given to Dr Condict a statement upon Oath for the Committee— Nomination of Van Buren yesterday rejected in the Senate.
28. VII. Saturday. Fahrenheit—2.

I was up till near Midnight. And it was seven this morning when I rose— In extreme cold weather I am apt to oversleep my time— I finished the version of the 71st. and began that of the 72d. Psalm— The Senate have taken off the injunction of secresy from their proceedings and debates on the nomination of Martin Van Buren, as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to Great Britain— Several of the Speeches against him were published in the National Intelligencer this Morning, and in reading them I was belated at the Committee room which I reached not till a quarter past eleven instead of half past ten— The members present were Condict, Horn Dayan and J. S. Barbour who did not however stay the Meeting out. Findlay and Worthington were absent— Dr Condict produced the Statement of Mr Schenk sworn to before a magistrate here. Also hints for a remedial Bill— Mr Horn read a Letter from a friend of his of the manufacturing interest— To remedy the frauds on the Revenue in the importation of Woolens, I proposed the discussion of the question whether the place of valuation of the imported Article should be changed from the place whence exported to the port of importation. Dr. Condict inclined to the change— Schenk and Brown were against it, on account of the fluctuations in the Market, much greater here than in England. Horn and Dayan were also against it, objecting that the operation of the principle of valuation here would require great additional labour at the Custom houses, and would produce a want of uniformity in the amount of duties payable on the same Articles according to the varying estimates of the Appraisers at different Ports— I was requested to see and converse with the Secretary of the Treasury on these points—also on the expediency of rectifying the value of the Pound Sterling as fixed by Law for our Custom-houses; and also of shortening the terms of credit upon importations— I shewed Dr Condict an Article circulating in the Southern Newspapers about what I said in the Committee of Manufactures of the necessity of mutual concession between the manufacturing and the Southern planting Interests in modifying the system of the Tariff— It was grossly misrepresented— Dr Condict said he had made the remark to the other members of the Committee this Morning. I called at
the Treasury Department and waited some time in the Anti-chamber— Met there Mr Wing, Delegate from Michigan, and Mr Hassler afterwards came in with his Reports in Manuscript upon weights and measures at the Custom-houses— I had half an hour’s conversation with Mr M’Lane— He strongly inclined to change the place of valuation of imported Articles as the best if not the only remedy against frauds in the importation of woolens—with regard to the shortening of the credits and the rectification of the value of the Pound Sterling, he gave no decided opinion; but said he would answer the enquiries of the Committee relating to the frauds at an early day— We think of reporting a separate Bill upon that Subject— I gave the name of Willard Phillips of Boston, as the proposed agent to collect the information desired respecting the manufactures— He said he would appoint him— We had a company of Gentlemen to dine: among whom the two Agents of the French Government de Beaumont and Tocqueville, who have been round to New-Orleans and through the Western Country since I met them at Mr Biddle’s in Philadelphia— I had a long conversation with Beaumont after dinner— He had many inquiries respecting the political and Literary Institutions of this Country. He complained of not having been able to obtain all the information he had desired on these Subjects; but spoke with great Satisfaction of what he had seen and heard at Boston.
29. VI. Sunday— Fahrenheit 20— Snow-Storm

This morning I was again belated in my rising— The 72d. Psalm is entitled of or for Solomon, and it is one of the most beautiful of the whole collection— For there are varieties of poetical beauty between them— It is indeed remarkable that of 150 lyric poems all upon the greatness and goodness of God, there should be such continual variety, with such constant sameness— There are a few primary ideas always repeated; but always under different modifications— This 72d. Psalm is understood to be prophetical and descriptive of Christ’s kingdom upon Earth.— But in its ostensible appearance it is a coronation hymn for Solomon, as the 45th. is an epithalium for the same Monarch— There seems to me to be a similarity of Style between these two Psalms classing them apart from the rest— This is a fervent supplication to God, that he would bestow upon Solomon the Spirit of wisdom and of goodness to discharge his duties as a king; and paints the blessed consequences to himself and to his People which would flow from this— The Sentences are all short; and the verses easily throw themselves into the forms of rhyme— But my Stanzas sound flat and unprofitable to myself even by the side of the prosaic English Bible— I heard this morning Mr Smith, from Acts 7.59. “And they stoned Stephen, calling upon God and saying, Lord Jesus, receive my Spirit.” Mr Smith appears to have one formula of announcing immediately after reading his text the doctrine that he proposes to draw from it— Thus after reading his text, he said the maxim to be drawn from it was that Jesus Christ was the only dependence of the Soul— And then he expatiated upon the history of Stephen the first Martyr—presented various views of life and death, of Time and Eternity and concluded by disclosing that his Sermon was occasioned upon the decease of two members of his Society— Mr Lee and Mr James of Boston were in the Pew— There came a fall of Snow which continued all the latter part of the day, and detained me at home from the afternoon
service— Chief Justice Marshall, and Judge Story visited me—before dinner. The Chief Justice told me that the debate in the Legislature of Virginia, upon the proposal for a gradual emancipation of the Slaves in the State was closed by a majority of about twenty for postponement of the Question, though in the form of rejecting the Resolution— Several of the members who voted against it declaring that they were individually in favour of it; but wished time and opportunity to ascertain the Sentiments of the People concerning it— Day and Evening spent upon this Diary— I received Letters from W. Sullivan and from Dr James W. Wallace—and from D. J. Pearce, a Rhode-Island Newspaper containing the minority Report, on the examination of charges against Masonry, by a Committee of the Legislature.
30. VI:30. Monday.

An impulse to finish the version of the 72d Psalm led me this morning to compose an additional or third Stanza, and I finished it— Rode to the Capitol and attended the Committee of Manufactures— Condict, Horn, Worthington, Dayan, J. S. Barbour were present. Findlay absent— The Resolution of the House, passed on the motion of Mr Nuckolls last Friday was read and I was instructed to refer it to the Secretary of the Treasury— Also a Memorial from Philadelphia, asking a modification of the 3d. Section of the Act of 26. May 1830. with a draught of a Bill by Mr Horn— Also the Affidavit of P. H. Schenk, and the Suggestions for the Amendment of the Law by him and Jonas B. Brown; and I was directed to enquire when we might expect answers to the calls for information respecting the modification of the Tariff— Adjourned to meet Thursday Morning— In the house I presented the Petition ofwhich was referred to the Committee of Claims I spoke to Mr Whittlesey the Chairman and recommended the petition to his attention. He referred to another case of Grice, and said the Committee thought the opinion of the Attorney General wrong— It was part of the jugglery of Amos Kendall against the Commissioners of the Navy— Dr Condict presented a Memorial from New-Jersey, concerning the Colonization of free people of Colour, which after a peppery debate without Salt and yeas and nays once taken, and two or three times threatened was finally referred to a Committee of 7— Mr Jenifer’s Resolution was not taken up now but will be referred to the same Committee— The apportionment Bill was taken up. Wickliffe’s proposition to recommit the Bill to a Committee of 24. one from each State, with Instructions to strike out 48000 and leave a blank was rejected by yeas and nays 114 to 76— Mr Hubbard then moved to strike out 48 and insert 44— This was a last and desperate chance— Wickliffe advised him not to specify the inserting number because he said he would certain lose it. But Hubbard insisted— As the question was about to be taken Burges moved an adjournment which was carried— The number of 48000 is so entrenched in the Bill that it is obviously impossible to dislodge it— Mrs Adams and the family were waiting for me at the door of the Capitol, and I rode home with them— While the house was in Session, I wrote an answer to the Letters received from William Sullivan; and a Letter to the Secretary of the Treasury, to enclose to him the papers referred to him by the Committee on Manufactures. It would be a great assistance to me if I could write one Letter every day while the house is in Session.
31. V:15. Tuesday.

Began the version of the 73d. Psalm. Mr Johnston of Louisiana called upon me this morning with his Colleague in the Senate newly elected Mr Waggaman, who apologized for not having called upon me before— They found me reading the Speeches still publishing, upon the nomination to the Senate of Martin Van-Buren as Minister to Great-Britain. Hayne and Miller from South-Carolina Poindexter of Mississippi, and Moore of Alabama, by uniting with them accomplished their object, with the casting vote of the Vice-President— Mr Johnston asked me if I knew anything of a Treaty negotiated by G. W. Erving in Spain, by which the Rio del Norte was to be the boundary between the United States and Mexico— I said there certainly never had been such a Treaty— He said the President had assured them that there was, and that the proof of it was in the Department of State— I said I had no doubt this was one of G. W. Erving’s lies, as there was not a greater liar upon Earth— That I was perswaded that the only colour for it that could be produced would be a Letter from him, written after the conclusion of the Treaty with Onis, in which detailing some interview that he had with the Spanish Minister Pizarro, he had said something from which Erving pretended to infer that they would give up the boundary to the Rio Bravo— Johnston said there was a Treaty with Mexico now before the Senate, which confirmed the boundary of the Treaty with Spain. That the people of Louisiana did not wish for the Province of Texas; but that the President believed in this Treaty of Erving’s— I said I knew the President had been labouring very hard to get this Province of Texas— That he would not get it by Treaty with Mexico; but I believed the increasing Settlements in Texas were all from this Country and that the inhabitants would prefer to belong to the United States rather than to Mexico; and it might perhaps be taken, as Florida was taken in 1812— But there would be one difficulty in it; as Slavery had been abolished in that Country. Johnston said that was only by a Military decree which the people there had resisted— It was only such a decree as Bolivar had issued in Colombia— I walked to the Capitol— In the House, Mr Jenifer’s Resolution was taken up, and with an amendment of Mr Archer was referred to the same Committee appointed upon the Memorial presented yesterday by Dr Condict— There was the same agitation which never fails to arise upon the approach to any topic connected with Slavery— Mr Edward Everett’s Resolution calling for a Copy of a Treaty with the Chickasaw Tribe of Indians, was taken up, and modified by him so as to limit the call to a copy of one Article of the Treaty. He supported it by a Speech deeply implicating the second Auditor of the Treasury, Major Lewis. Mr Bell of Tennessee answered, somewhat equivocally—avowing a disposition not to oppose the call, but arguing against it— He was followed by T. R. Mitchell, and Wickliffe who opposed the Call— The discussion was arrested by the expiration of the hour— The apportionment Bill was taken up, on the Motion to strike out 48000. Slade made a long and sensible Speech. Arnold, Kerr—Wilde short ones— The yeas and nays were taken 94 for and 99 against striking out— Hubbard then moved to strike out 48000 and insert 44500. upon which Wilde moved and carried an adjournment— Rode home— Mr Ricketts a maker of Piano Fortes was here this Evening and said the musical instrument makers were about to petition Congress were about to petition for an increase of duty upon imported Musical Instruments, and asked if I would present their petition— I told him I would.

Day. Like the last preceding Month— But the house sits later—business accumulates and becomes more oppressive— A crisis of my own fate for the remnant of my life, is rolling down upon me, like burning Lava from Vesuvius— [symbols]
